results.title: Luke's party
results.creator_credit: Ros Sultan, Tim Burns and AFI [au]
results.brief_description: A woman picks up a video camera to make a mock documentary about growing up as a First Nations person in South Australia. As the camera starts rolling she is continually interrupted by the demands of children, friends, telephone repair people, neighbours, salespeople and representatives of a range of government bureaucracies. This delightfully tongue-in-cheek short film makes salient points about the difficulties of maintaining personal dignity in a world of economic and emotional uncertainty. The futility of her attempt to explain “herself” on camera as the world around her descends into absurd farce satirises the pretend objectivity of most social-realist documentary. Sharp, witty and surprisingly passionate, “Luke’s Party” is an exceptional short Australian film.

results.title: Deadly
results.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Richard Moir, Moirstorm Productions and Beyond Films
results.brief_description: To clear his name, disgraced city cop Tony Bourke (Jerome Ehlers) is sent to file a report on the “suicide” hanging of a local First Nations person in a remote outback gaol. His orders are to clean things up quickly and quietly but, in a town ready to explode with racial tension, Bourke uncovers a web of suspicion and the truth behind a deadly secret. A fast-paced thriller and intriguing and powerful story of conspiracy, cover-up and cold-blooded murder. Features Tony Barry and Bill Hunter.

results.title: Freedom rides
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers”.
Charles Perkins grew up in Alice Springs in a time when racial segregation was the rule. Sent away to Adelaide for an education he became increasingly aware of the injustices perpetrated against Australian First Nations peoples. In 1965 he instigated the “Freedom ride” - a busload of concerned people, mostly students - who visited outback Australia, notably Walgett and Moree, to escalate the level of public awareness of racial intolerance in Australia. This video documents that journey and talks to those who took part.

results.title: Family life
results.creator_credit: Tony Chenn, Ugo Mariotti and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Fairfield in Sydney is a community of diverse ethnic groups. This program looks at families from three of these groups - Australian First Nations people, Iola-Australian and Anglo-Saxon/Kampuchean. Each family is observed as they discuss how they cope and intend to cope with the cultural differences which surround them.

results.title: The Hurdle
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Nick Torrens and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Striving”.
Douglas Sam, Australia’s best middleweight boxer, had to overcome enormous psychological pressures at the Commonwealth Games of 1982 in Brisbane. Douglas is an Australian First Nations man, and many of his people felt that he should not compete in these games. He did compete and the news media made Douglas a favourite for a gold medal. This film traces his wins and his losses.

results.title: Making a stone axe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Shows how Australia’s First Nations peoples lived hundreds of years ago. Tool making require both skill and patience. By means of grinding stones, the stone axe is shaped to the desired form.

results.title: Emu hunt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Hunting for the emu. Two men after finding eggs follow the spoor across the desert, with their spears held ready to catch their prey.

results.title: Fishing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Illustrates the fishing methods of some Australian First Nations people, shown fishing on a lake using three-pronged spears from bark canoes. With Bill Onus.

results.title: The Dreaming
results.creator_credit: Judy Campbell, Geoffrey Collings, Dahl Collings and Collings Productions
results.brief_description: An exploration of Australian First Nations rock paintings in Arnhem Land that attempts to capture the cultural and spiritual significance and meaning of the art to the local peoples.

results.title: Crocodile hunters
results.creator_credit: Lee Robinson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: In the rivers and billabongs of Northern Territory small fresh-water crocodiles are traditionally hunted using spear and canoe. But, in recent years, a new industry has become established in these regions - the hunting of the crocodile for his skin, which brings a high price in the south when manufactured into hand-bags, shoes, wallets and ornaments. Teams of hunters make their camps by the rivers and estuaries where fresh-water and salt-water varieties are found. Photography by Frank Bagnall.
